thread.title: Thunderbirds to showcase precision during national anthem at Super Bowl LI
thread.title_full: Thunderbirds to showcase precision during national anthem at Super Bowl LI

author: Andrea Rumbaugh
title: Thunderbirds to showcase precision during national anthem at Super Bowl LI

organizations.name: u.s. air force air demonstration squadron

text:
Image 12 of 13 Coldplay Queen Bey has established a reputation as a stellar performer, and her 2016 Super Bowl appearance was no exception. Oh, and Coldplay and Bruno Mars offered Beyoncé good background singers and dancers. less Coldplay Queen Bey has established a reputation as a stellar performer, and her 2016 Super Bowl appearance was no exception. Oh, and Coldplay and Bruno Mars offered Beyoncé good background singers and ... more Photo: Patrick Smith, Getty Images Image 13 of 13 Thunderbirds to showcase precision during national anthem at Super Bowl LI 1 / 13 Back to Gallery 
The U.S. Air Force Thunderbirds will showcase their renowned precision Sunday when they fly over NRG Stadium at a very specific point of the national anthem: as Luke Bryan holds the "A" in "home of the brave." 
Planning that moment has required a lot of coordination because once the F-16s begin flying toward the stadium, they can only speed up or slow down their arrival by 10 seconds. 
"For each stanza of the national anthem, we have a time and distance for where the airplanes should be," said Capt. Erik Gonsalves, Thunderbird No. 8, who will be in the stadium helping coordinate the timing. 
GETTING READY: Lady Gaga dances in a bra during sexy sneak peek at halftime show 
On Friday, the Thunderbirds met with Super Bowl LI singers to measure the length of their performances. Before Bryan sings the national anthem, original "Hamilton" cast members Phillipa Soo, Renée Elise Goldsberry and Jasmine Cephas Jones will perform a rendition of "America The Beautiful." 
On Saturday afternoon, they practiced flying over NRG Stadium. Gonsalves had said ground coordinators planned to toss a few curve balls at the Thunderbirds just in case "Luke Bryan really gets in the moment and starts drawing out some of those stanzas." 
But overcast skies limited the Thunderbirds to one flyover with no curve balls. 
For the big game, the Thunderbirds will take off about a half-hour before the national anthem and make large, left-hand turns in an area 25 to 35 miles south of the stadium. It will take them about four minutes and 30 seconds to get to the stadium, so they will begin that flight during the middle of "America the Beautiful." 
RELATED: Law enforcement eyes will be in sky over stadium area 
Gonsalves will be inside the stadium with the production team and production studios. Three additional Thunderbirds will be on the stadium's roof to communicate with the six pilots flying the F-16s. 
This is Gonsalves' first Super Bowl, and he gets to stay to watch the game. All 12 Thunderbird officers will be recognized during the game. 
"I'm really excited," Gonsalves said. "It's such a cool opportunity, and what an honor to be able to come out here and do this." 
The Thunderbirds are officially called the U.S. Air Force Air Demonstration Squadron. Their mission is to plan and present precision aerial maneuvers to exhibit the capabilities of modern, high-performance aircraft and the degree of skill required to operate those aircraft. Most Read
